text.p:
This common order will govern all the captioned four writ
petitions.

2. Mr.K.Selvaraj, learned counsel for writ petitioners in all four
writ petitions are before this virtual Court. Learned counsel submits that
there are four different writ petitioners, but the issue is same. Learned
counsel submits that the writ petitioners were given two years license
(from 2019 to 2021) for selling short eats and collecting empty bottles
from Bars attached to four different retail liquor outlets run by 'Tamil
Nadu State Marketing Corporation Limited' ['TASMAC'], but in 2019-
2021 period, Corona virus pandemic and consequent lock down which is
collectively referred to as 'COVID 19 situation', which the writ petitioner
could neither portend nor presage, intervened. Learned counsel for writ
petitioners submits that there was lock down and therefore, writ
petitioners could not have the benefit of entire two years period.

3. Notwithstanding the expansive prayer in all the four writ
petitions, learned counsel, on instructions, abridges the prayer and
restricts the prayer to a simple Mandamus to dispose of representations
all dated 27.08.2021 made by each of the four writ petitioners. The
details are as follows:

text.p:
4. Mr.K.Sathish Kumar, learned standing counsel for TASMAC,
accepts notice on behalf of all the 3 respondents in all the four writ
petitions. On instructions, learned standing counsel submits that no fee
was collected from the writ petitioners during the lock down period.

5. However, owing to the extremely limited abridged/restricted
prayer writ petitioners are now making, this Court deems it appropriate to
accede to the limited abridged prayer.

6. Before this Court proceeds further, it is deemed appropriate to
extract and reproduce four representations that has been placed before
Court (as part of the common typed set of papers). The four
representations are as follows:

7. Captioned four writ petitions are disposed of with a directive to
first respondent to consider and dispose of all the four writ petitioners'
representations (all dated 27.08.2021) on its own merits, in accordance
with law as expeditiously as the business of the first respondent would
permit and in any event, within three weeks from today i.e., on or before
15.11.2021.

8. Proceedings/orders disposing all the aforementioned four
representations of the four writ petitioners shall be communicated to the
respective writ petitioners under due acknowledgment within five
working days from the dates of disposal of the representations. Though
obvious, it is made clear that this Court has not expressed any opinion or
view on the merits of the matter and the first respondent shall consider
the representations on their own merits and in accordance with law.

9. Captioned four Writ Petitions are disposed of in the aforesaid
manner by this common order. There shall be no order as to costs.
